Fields.DialogueText: Hello! You're... Voykov, right?
Da.
Well, I'm your Captain... and I have a couple of duties for you to see to right now.
Khorosho. Okay, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: Are you okay? Is there... something wrong?
A little more respect would be in order.
Two can play at that game...

Fields.DialogueText: Nyet, nothing's wrong. I'll do whatever you need me to do in no time at all. Leave me to it.
If that's what you want...
I'm not sure what you mean...
Are you the rebellious sort? Because I can tell you now, I will have little patience for that sort of behavior aboard this ship.
I'm not trying to be obstinate in any way. I just like to be alone. You can trust that I'll always get the work done.
All... right, then.
Kapitan, I see Morganas quickly approaching. We should probably take care of them.
O... okay. Everyone! Get to your stations!
@BATTLE
Voykov! Why are you just sitting around? Is everything okay?
I already finished all my work.
There's no way. There was so much on that list!
It's all done, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: You were supposed to organize cleaning the deck. Are you really telling me...?
Huh. Keep up the good work, then.
Why don't you go dust everyone's cabin?

Fields.DialogueText: Already been done.
Khorosho.
That request sounds ridiculous. I feel compelled to refuse, Kapitan.
Never mind that, I see Morganas in the horizon. Everyone, man your stations!
@BATTLE
Damn... Voykov, that was fine work.
I told you I can get my work done.
I believe you.
There are Morganas astern! Crew, prepare for battle!
We're ready for them, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
Voykov, you're covered in blood! Are you okay?! We need to get you to the infirmary right away!
What? I'm fine - what are you talking about?
All the... all the blood that you're covered in. You're hurt, aren't you?
Oh! Nyet, I'm all right. This is not my blood.

Fields.MenuText: You are ruthless! I can respect that.
... Please tell me you've been helping in the infirmary.
I'm going to walk away now. I'm... slightly afraid.

Fields.DialogueText: I think you misinterpret what you see here.
Almost. Khoroshaya dogadka.
Oh, it's just a little blood. You're the kapitan of this ship - I'm sure you'd be accustomed to seeing as much.
One of the crew was hurt during the battle. I assisted in stopping the bleeding. As you can see, he lost a lot of blood, but the doctors think he'll survive.
Oh! And you... you're not disturbed?
Plenty disturbs me, Kapitan, but not the blood of my crew.
Voykov, you are... so very interesting.
If you'll excuse me, I'm going to go clean up.
Have fun...
Voykov! I hate to ask this of you, but since you're the only crew member ahead of schedule, I was wondering if I could assign you an extra task. I...
... Are you listening to orchestral music?
Yes. Do you have a problem with that?
Not at all! It's just so surprising considering how... tense you seem.
Not all of it is soft like this. But as a whole, the music puts me in the right mindset. I can't do anything if I haven't listened to my music.

Fields.MenuText: I'm the same way! Something about the beautifully paired instruments just gets the blood coursing through my veins.
I like music with a more swingy, jazzy sound. It gets me energized!
I've never thought about turning to music to help me get work done. That's a really good idea.

Fields.DialogueText: If I'm being completely honest, popular music just irritates me. I like good, clean, classical music.
It certainly gets me a nice, pounding headache.
You should try it, then. I can't imagine living otherwise.
Would you mind if I listen with you?
I'm sorry, Kapitan, but my alone time is important to me. I would be open to listening together later, however.
Kapitan! Voykov! We need you both on deck! The Neizvestniy flot are back!
So much for my alone time.
@BATTLE
I need everyone on deck! The Morganas are coming in fast and there are a lot of them!
Isn't that always the way?
@BATTLE
Voykov... how do you fight like that? You seem calmly resigned to fight without remorse or restraint.
Oh, Kapitan. I have no remorse. The way I see it, I have a job to do, and it's important that I do it in the most efficient way possible.
You don't ever feel anything? Like, doing something violent and not giving it a second thought?
Why would I feel sorry for beating down those who wish to do others harm? And I find the very concept of souls to be rather trite.
Spirituality as a whole is ridiculous.
You don't believe in souls?
No, why? Do you?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, in fact, I do! God blessed each of us with a unique one.
No, I think that stuff is absolutely ridiculous. We're just bodies made up of flesh and organs. We don't have souls, we just have brains.
I mean... I'd like to believe that there's something inside of us. We can't just be a body of flesh. Where do we get our morality and judgment and emotions?

Fields.DialogueText: To each their own, I guess...
Exactly! There's no proof for any of it and it all just seems so unlikely. There's no point in believing in it.
Our brains. The way I see it, souls and God and the afterlife are just ridiculous methods people have come up with to make themselves feel better, nothing more.
This is a lively conversation we're having.
It was... fine, I guess. But I'd rather go before we start 'bonding'.
Voykov? Where are you? Voykov? Are you in the - oh, hell, I'm so sorry!
Get out! Out, out, out!
I didn't know you were in there... I'm really sorry...
So... was that a box of hair dye I saw? You're not a natural blonde?
Nyet. So what? Is there something wrong with that?

Fields.MenuText: It's just... isn't that usually associated with women who...
No... nothing wrong with that. I just thought Belles had easier ways to change their appearances.
No! It looks good! I would have never known otherwise.

Fields.DialogueText: You really don't want to finish that sentence.
No such luck for me.
I suppose... that's kind of you to say.
Why do you dye your hair?
To be different.
Different from other people?
To be different from who I was.
What do you mean?
Kapitan! Neizvestniy flot is quickly approaching!
Come on. We have more important matters to attend to.
@BATTLE
Hello, Voykov! I'm guessing you finished your work?
Da, Kapitan.
What's that you're reading?
Do you really care, or are you just trying to make conversation?
I care. I'm always looking for new reading material.
I'm reading Crime and Punishment. I've read it multiple times already, but I always find something new in it. Its ideas are very... thought provoking.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, God, that sounds so boring... I find science fiction much more appealing.
Hm. I've read it, but not in wartime. I think Raskolnikov's philosophies might have a different flavor to them when you're under fire.
I guess that sounds kind of interesting... although, if I'm being completely honest with myself, I'll never have enough time to read.

Fields.DialogueText: I like what I like. You don't have to be so judgmental...
An interesting point! And more proof that reading is invaluable in learning to understand how others think.
So... you were just trying to make conversation?
Hey, maybe I could give you some recommendations sometime!
I suppose that would be acceptable... Oh... I can hear the Neizvestniy flot. We better go take care of them. They're getting close.
@BATTLE
Privet, Kapitan. Do you have any extra ink?
I always do. Are you getting ahead on your paperwork?
I'm working on my memoirs.

Fields.MenuText: Interesting. Is this just your career as an awoken Belle, or going all the way back to 1914?
I have no idea where you'll find the time - but I'm impressed. I wish you luck with your project.
That sounds like a big endeavor... Are you sure you're up for the task?

Fields.DialogueText: I will try to cover my entire life - though it's certainly easier to organize my thoughts about more recent events.
It's not a matter of luck, Kapitan. Only dedication.
Are you questioning my writing ability? Of course I'm up for the task!
I have every confidence in you. And... okay, here's your ink.
Thank you, Kapitan.
I would be available to proofread for you, if you think that might help.
Uh... sure. If you're really interested.
Kapitan! We have Neizvestniy flot approaching! We need you in the bridge!
We'll be right there! Come on, Voykov.
@BATTLE
Kapitan! I need to talk to you immediately!
What's wrong, Voykov? Is something going on?!
Da! One of the crew members refuses to acknowledge that his opinion on aristocracy is incorrect.
That's... that's it? I don't know what you want me to do.
I'll tell you my opinion on the subject, and we'll go from there.
I think I can guess the gist of your opinion.
Aristocracy is a painful remnant of a social order that exploited the bulk of humanity in favor of a parasitical overclass.
And... Communism under Stalin is a necessary corrective and the next step toward a fully just, fully realized global society?
Da, that's it. What do you think?

Fields.MenuText: I don't know, Voykov. I've met too many Soviet citizens who don't feel it's safe to speak their minds. It's hard to see that as a radical improvement over what other systems offer.
I really don't want to get in the middle of this. You should really go ask someone else.
You're not wrong about hereditary social stations, at least. You're never going to hear me say that being the grandchild of a duke makes anyone better than anyone else.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan! We've spoken of this before - ruthless methods are, at times, needed to protect the lives of many.
But I would very much like to know your opinion on the subject.
Exactly! Please come tell that mush-for-brains crew member that! Maybe he'll listen to you.
Voykov, I really have to get back to work... Damn it, now the Morganas are back! Come on, let's go.
@BATTLE
Voykov, I need your opinion on something... Wait. Voykov... what are you reading?
Nichego takogo. Nothing! What do you need my opinion on?
Oh, it was just some silly little thing. This seems a lot more important. What are you reading? Don't try to hide the book!
Oh, no, what's that? The Neizvestniy flot! Kapitan, we need to get ready to battle!
How convenient...
@BATTLE
Admit it, Voykov. You were reading Trotsky!
Nyet. I deny it absolutely.
Fine.

Fields.MenuText: Why are you embarrassed? Some would say he was a far better man - and even a better Soviet - than Stalin.
I guess I could see why you wouldn't want this getting back to Moscow.
Maybe you're not as ruthless as I initially assumed you were.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't have to explain myself to you.
If you tell anyone, I guarantee you will be on the receiving end of the full force of my fury.
Try testing that assumption, and you'll find yourself quickly proven wrong.
Sorry, sorry, Voykov. I'm sorry, I shouldn't have pushed.
Apology accepted. Now, leave me alone.
Yes, Voykov...
Um... Voykov? There's something I need to talk to you about.
In a moment, Kapitan. If I'm not mistaken, there are some Morganas coming in off the port bow!
@BATTLE
Now, back to what I was talking about before... It has come to my attention that you are, apparently, swindling the crew of their money.
Swindling is a strong word. I'm merely engaging them in different kinds of... games.
Are you making bets and gambling with my crew?
Da, Kapitan. I am.

Fields.MenuText: How in the world could you possibly think that that's appropriate?!
Since I am your captain, can I... get a cut of the money?
Look... I won't stop you, but please try to make your 'games' a little more fair. I don't want to hear any more complaints.

Fields.DialogueText: I was just trying to have fun!
If you let me continue, fine. I'll give you 30%.
Da, Kapitan. I understand.
How do you get yourself into these kinds of messes?
They're hardly messes for me if I'm the one always doing the winning.
Kapitan! I finished the first several chapters of my memoirs.
Congratulations!
Remember how you said you would be interested in proofreading for me? I have those chapters with me right now...
Yes, of course. Right after we take care of those Morganas. I hate how they're always around...
@BATTLE
How's the reading coming?
Of your writing? I've almost finished this chapter...
Keep in mind, it's still rough... What do you think?

Fields.MenuText: I had no idea you've had so many names over the course of your life. It's a wonder you answer me at all when I call you!
You travelled the Northern Sea Route? That's impressive. I've heard how treacherous it can be...
You've been part of both the Baltic Fleet and the Pacific Fleet. That's a lot of responsibility.

Fields.DialogueText: You get used to the changes, after a while...
I must say, I'm not terribly fond of ice, now.
I was honored to be a part of both.
Voykov, this is quite the read! I'm really enjoying it. I'll get back to you later when I've read these chapters in full.
Spasibo, Kapitan.
*ALARM*
Ah, Voykov! There you are!
What is it, sir?
I have your memoir right here! I actually just finished reading it, and...
*ALARM*
Of course. Everyone, prepare for battle!
@BATTLE
Those Morganas are such a nuisance. But, back to what I was saying. I finally finished reading those chapters you gave me.
Khorosho! What did you think?

Fields.MenuText: I have absolutely no doubts now - you are certifiably insane!
You certainly have lived an incredible life so far. I can only imagine what you'll do in the future.
It was a bit slow for my taste...

Fields.DialogueText: Is that a good thing?
I'm hopeful I'll have plenty more tales to add to my memoirs.
You're being sarcastic, right? I'm sure you're being sarcastic.
Let me know when you have more chapters written! I'd love to read them!
Da, Kapitan. I would like that.
Voykov, there's something I wanted to ask you.
So many questions for me all the time. Da, Kapitan?
I've never understood why you carry that empty bottle around with you all the time. What's the point?
Ah, memories of the past.
... What was in there?
Ne seychas! I see Neizvestniy flot to our north.
@BATTLE
Voykov! I'm really curious now - what was in that bottle?
Hydrochloric acid.

Fields.MenuText: What memories could you possibly have involving hydrochloric acid?!
You know what... I don't want to know. I'm very afraid, and I'm just going to leave that subject alone.
How in the world did you get your hands on hydrochloric acid?

Fields.DialogueText: Shh, it's okay. Don't worry about it.
That's your choice. There's quite the story that goes along with it...
It's all part of the story.
You know, I think I'm just going to walk away now.
Voykov! I didn't know you need glasses to see.
Oh, I don't.
But... you're clearly holding a pair of glasses right now.
That doesn't mean I use them.
I can't imagine you would. They're broken! Why do you have broken glasses?
Chert. Those damn Neizvestniy flot hags are back. We can talk later, Kapitan.
@BATTLE
Voykov, tell me what those broken glasses are all about.
They're... um. They're similar to ones Trotsky had.

Fields.MenuText: I've never seen someone so determined to cover up their obsession with someone.
I'm sorry, I didn't hear you. Something about Trotsky again? I'm not surprised!
It's isn't a terrible thing to be so dedicated to someone.

Fields.DialogueText: Hush, you.
You are a mean one, Kapitan.
We're changing the subject now, Kapitan.
Are you still pretending that you prefer Stalin to Trotsky?
I'm leaving now, Kapitan. Continue talking, if you wish - the crew will think you rather strange, though.
Voykov! When you rolled up your sleeves earlier, I saw... Do you have a tattoo?
Da, Kapitan! We are all sailors here. Don't pretend you're surprised.
I guess it isn't a huge shock. What does it mean? I'm having a little trouble reading it.
It says 'It was' - but in my native Russian, of course. It means a lot to me.

Fields.MenuText: It's very minimalist. I think it looks nice.
Getting a tattoo is so improper! You shouldn't mark up your body with ink like that!
I wish I had your bravery! I want a tattoo, but I'm too scared of the pain.

Fields.DialogueText: Spasibo, Kapitan. I put a lot of thought into it.
It's my choice, isn't it? Besides, it holds a lot of importance to me.
Honestly, it's worth every second of the pain if you know that you really want it.
Why do those two words mean so much to you? It seems like such a simple phrase.
To me, it represents change. In the past, things were a certain way, but now they're completely different. Nothing is ever reliably stable.
I guess that's one way to look at life... Although, I'd say I can always rely on the Morganas returning. All hands on deck!
@BATTLE
Voykov, can I come in?
Of course, Kapitan. What do you need?
Oh, nothing. I picked up a book the last time I was in port, and thought you might like it.
That's kind of you, Kapitan. What book?

Fields.MenuText: "Anna Karenina" by Leo Tolstoy.
"The Brothers Karamazov" by Fyodor Dostoyevsky.
"And Quiet Flows the Don" by Mikhail Sholokhov.

Fields.DialogueText: I've read Anna Karenina, but I've been wanting to read it again. I appreciate you giving this to me!
I don't have my own copy of The Brothers Karamazov. Spasibo, Kapitan!
I've only ever heard of this book. Spasibo for thinking of me.
I hope you enjoy the book. I really tried to find something I thought you would like.
I'll tell you my thoughts after I've finished it - how does that sound?
That sounds great. Although, you might want to put off your reading until after we've taken out the incoming Morganas.
@BATTLE
Kapitan! I finished the book you gave me.
You're a fast reader, that's for sure. Did you like it as much as I thought you would?
I enjoyed it immensely. Thank you again for your thoughtfulness.
I'm happy to hear that.
Now, I know that I don't have quite as many books as you, but I thought I would return the favor and loan you a book. I expect you to take it.
Oh... okay! What do you have?
"Moby Dick" by Herman Melville, "Pride and Prejudice" by Jane Austen, and "A Doll's House" by Henrik Ibsen. All Western works, obviously - I've been branching out.

Fields.MenuText: I'll take "Moby Dick" any day! It seems fitting, don't you think? Although I hope that our story won't be quite so depressing.
"Pride and Prejudice"... but don't laugh!
I've heard that "A Doll's House" is excellent, and I like the idea of reading a play.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm afraid I can't give you any guarantees on the matter of the subject, Kapitan.
I think you'll like it! It's full of sarcasm, which I think you'll appreciate.
It certainly is the more exotic choice. Its story is excellent.
I greatly appreciate you giving me this!
Of course, Kapitan. I do have a couple others with me if you finish that one.
I'll try my best to read in my free time, but it always seems like those damn Morganas are around to ruin the fun.
@BATTLE
Voykov, are you still working?
Da, I was unable to finish my duties as quickly as I usually do.
It's fine. You're still far ahead of the rest of the crew.
I don't know... I'm just... I'm not feeling well.
What do you mean? What's wrong?
I'm... just a little lightheaded, I think.
That's not good... and we have Morganas closing in, it appears. Can you fight?
It will take more than a little lightheadedness to keep me from doing my duty.
@BATTLE
Voykov, you did well in battle, but I can tell you still don't feel well. Do you know what's wrong?
Nyet, I'm just dizzy and kind of... confused? I don't know...

Fields.MenuText: You need to go lie down.
How about you finish up the little bit of work you have left and then rest for a while?
I'm sure you're fine, it's probably just a little seasickness. You can power through it.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm fine, I'm fine. I can keep going. Don't worry about me.
I can keep going for the whole day, it's fine. Do you have any extra work I can do?
Da, Kapitan. I'm sure I can.
I'll be keeping an eye on you, though; just in case anything happens.
Fine. But I'm sure... I'll be fine.
*ALARM*
Voykov? Where are you? Voykov!
You haven't found her yet, Captain?
I'm worried. I have no idea where she could be... She hasn't started her duties either, which is completely out of character.
I'm here, Kapitan...
Are you okay? Look at your face, you're so pale! You need to rest, Voykov.
I'm just dizzy, it's fine. This boat is moving so much...
It's... it's really not. Let me take you back to bed.
Nyet! Look, there are Neizvestniy flot witches out on the horizon! Let me show you how well I can fight!
@BATTLE
Okay... well, I'll admit that your skills in battle aren't that impaired, but I'm still worried about you.
I'm fine...

Fields.MenuText: No, you're not! Go to bed!
Can you please go to bed? Come with me, I'll take you there.
I'll trust you, but I'm going to be watching you. If you show any sign of weakness, I'm taking you to bed.

Fields.DialogueText: I'll do what I want.
I'm... fine. Really.
I never show signs of weakness.
(I don't know what I'm going to do with her...)
Voykov, I brought you some food! Voykov? Where did she go now?
*ALARM*
Damn it, that's just what we needed...
@BATTLE
Voykov, what's happening? Were you hurt during the battle? Why are all of these doctors here?
I'm fine now...
What happened?
I... had a seizure.
What? You... what? Belles can have seizures?
I... have epilepsy. Or something like it. The doctors, they can only guess, really.

Fields.MenuText: Voykov, why didn't you tell me that?! I've been so worried...
So these have been symptoms leading up to an attack?
You could've been seriously injured!

Fields.DialogueText: Prosti, Kapitan. I didn't mean to worry you. I just didn't want to burden you.
Da...
Prosti... Please don't be mad. I didn't want to burden you...
Are you still feeling dizzy? Come on, we need to get you back to bed.
I'm sorry...
Please stop apologizing.
I brought you some stuff! Food, water, and the medication...
I don't think that medication was made for Belles, Kapitan.
Hmm... You're probably right.
I appreciate your concern, but you really didn't need to go to so much trouble.

Fields.MenuText: Yes, I did. I should have seen what was going on.
I'm taking care of you, and you don't have a say in the matter.
Fine, if you really think you can take care of yourself...

Fields.DialogueText: It wasn't your fault. Please don't say that.
Excuse me? I most certainly do.
I do. Please trust me.
The attacks I have are rare. It should be some time before I have another.
*ALARM*
Stay here. I'll take care of everything.
Over my dead body.
@BATTLE
Damn, Voykov, you really are something.
I don't neglect my duties. That's all there is to it.
Voykov! What are you doing here? I thought I was the only person who knew about this part of the ship.
... It's easy to forget who I'm talking to sometimes.
Would you rather I not be here?

Fields.MenuText: No, it's fine. You're free to go wherever you want on the ship. Except my quarters, of course...
I would really prefer it if you didn't... This is kind of my private place...
I feel bad enough about your seizure, that I wouldn't stand in the way of you going anywhere.

Fields.DialogueText: Spasibo! I like coming here to think.
Oh... Prosti. My apologies.
Stop feeling bad. I've told you - it wasn't your fault.
Is everything all right? You look as if you have something on your mind.
Da. Actually something has been bothering me.
*ALARM*
Will it wait until later?
Da. It can wait.
@BATTLE
There you are, Voykov. Now, what was it you wanted to say, earlier?
We don't have to talk about it, if you're busy. It isn't important...
*ALARM*
We will talk about it... right after we've taken care of these Morganas.
@BATTLE
Now, Voykov. Tell me what's bothering you.
... I know I'm a soulless creature, Kapitan. But sometimes I question... I doubt. What if I do have a soul? How wretched of a person would I be, if so?

Fields.MenuText: Stop, don't say that. I've seen every side of you - strong, weak, kind, abrasive. All of it. You're not wretched. I can promise you that.
Everyone wrestles with doubts, Voykov. It's not wrong to do so. It's how we realize what's true about ourselves.
I'm not sure I can give you the answer to that question, Voykov - it's for you to determine. But I'll do whatever I can to help in your deliberation.

Fields.DialogueText: I appreciate your words, Kapitan.
I do sometimes think such doubts are problematic, but perhaps you're right - wrestling with them could be a good thing.
Spasibo, but this is something I need to do by myself. I appreciate your support, but this is an inner journey.
I like you, Voykov. I'm so happy you're a part of my team.
Spasibo, Kapitan.
Kapitan? There you are.
Hello, Voykov!
You look as if you have something on your mind, now. What's wrong?
Nothing's wrong. I just... I've been thinking.
Wait! There are some Neizvestniy flot pests to exterminate off the port bow. We need to get the crew ready for battle.
@BATTLE
I'm sorry that the Neizvestniy flot thought it was to interrupt you, Kapitan. What did you want to talk about?

Fields.MenuText: I just wanted to tell you that you're a great friend. I love having you on this ship, and I'm glad we've gotten to know one another better.
Voykov... you're really special to me. And, no matter the doubts you have, I just want you to remember that. I'll always have your back.

Fields.DialogueText: That's very nice of you to say, Kapitan. Spasibo.
Thank you, Kapitan. You're... special to me, as well.
You know, I've finished another chapter in my memoir.
Have you? Well then, I think it's time I give it a read.
